image_1.context: Lewis Carroll was the pseudonym of the Revd Charles Lutwidge Dodgson, born 27 January $_{\mathrm{I}}8_{32}$ at Daresbury, Cheshire. He went to Christ Church, Oxford, in $\boldsymbol{\mathrm{~I~}}\!\!85\boldsymbol{\mathrm{I}}$ , where he became a Senior Student, and lived there for the rest of his life. He was Mathematical Lecturer $(\mathbf{\sigma}_{\mathbf{I}}8_{55}5\substack{-8\,\mathbf{I}})$ and was admitted to deacon’s orders in 1861, although he did not proceed to priest’s orders. He was a noted photographer, especially of children, a prolific diarist, letter-writer and pamphleteer; although in some ways reclusive, THROUGH THE LOOKING-GLASS ALICE’S ADVENTURES IN WONDERLAND and oxford world’s classics  OXFORDWORLD'SCLASSICS Alice's Adventures inWonderland andThroughtheLooking-Glass Lewis Carroll
image_1.description: The image depicts a whimsical and colorful scene featuring a character resembling the Queen of Hearts from Lewis Carroll's 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'. The queen is dressed in a vibrant, ornate costume with a blue dress adorned with gold and red patterns. She wears a large, triangular black hat with a golden crown on top. Her expression is stern and commanding, with her mouth set in a firm line. In her left hand, she holds a plate with several red tarts, each topped with what appears to be jam or jelly. To her right, there is a smaller figure, possibly a card soldier, who is also dressed in a similar style with a crown and holding a scepter. The background features a lush garden with green hedges shaped like hearts and flowers, adding to the fantastical atmosphere. Butterflies can be seen fluttering around, enhancing the magical setting. The overall mood of the image conveys a sense of authority and fantasy, typical of the story's themes.

image_2.context: Lewis Carroll was the pseudonym of the Revd Charles Lutwidge Dodgson, born 27 January $_{\mathrm{I}}8_{32}$ at Daresbury, Cheshire. He went to Christ Church, Oxford, in $\boldsymbol{\mathrm{~I~}}\!\!85\boldsymbol{\mathrm{I}}$ , where he became a Senior Student, and lived there for the rest of his life. He was Mathematical Lecturer $(\mathbf{\sigma}_{\mathbf{I}}8_{55}5\substack{-8\,\mathbf{I}})$ and was admitted to deacon’s orders in 1861, although he did not proceed to priest’s orders. He was a noted photographer, especially of children, a prolific diarist, letter-writer and pamphleteer; although in some ways reclusive, he had a wide range of acquaintances THROUGH THE LOOKING-GLASS ALICE’S ADVENTURES IN WONDERLAND and oxford world’s classics  Lewis Carroll Alice's Adventures inWonderland andThroughtheLooking-Glass OXFORDWORLD'SCLASSICS
image_2.description: The image depicts a decorative element with a symmetrical design. The central motif is an ornate shield-like shape with a blue and gold color scheme. The shield features intricate patterns, including a starburst design at the top and a stylized emblem in the center. Flanking the shield are two red objects that resemble ceremonial maces or scepters, each resting on a surface that appears to be a stone or marble ledge. image_3.image_path: ./fusion_research/fusion_dataset/novel/Alices Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass (Lewis Carroll) (1)/images/image_3.jpg
image_3.context: Imperious Prima flashes forth Her edict ‘to begin it’: In gentler tones Secunda hopes ‘There will be nonsense in it!’ While Tertia\* interrupts the tale Ah, cruel Three! In such an hour, Beneath such dreamy weather, To beg a tale of breath too weak To stir the tiniest feather! Yet what can one poor voice avail Against three tongues together? All in the golden afternoon Full leisurely we glide; For both our oars, with little skill, By little arms are plied, While little hands make vain pretence Our wanderings to guide. Publication of Sylvie and Bruno Concluded; Pillow Problems (Curiosa Mathematica II). 1894 Rudyard Kipling, The Jungle Book. 1895 G. E. Dies at ‘The Chestnuts’, Guildford; (Feb.) publication of Three Sunsets and Other Poems; (Dec.) The Life and Letters of Lewis Carroll (dated 1899).
image_3.description: The image is a black-and-white illustration from 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland.' It depicts a courtroom scene with various characters. At the center, there is a king and queen seated on thrones, both wearing crowns and robes. The king holds a scepter and has a surprised expression, while the queen looks stern and angry. To the left of the king, a rabbit dressed in a suit stands holding a scroll. On the right side of the queen, a man in a tall hat and uniform stands guard. Below the royal couple, a bird-like creature sits at a table with a plate of food, seemingly eating. Another character, possibly a knight, stands to the left of the bird, holding a shield and sword. The background features large windows with curtains and a coat of arms with hearts. The overall atmosphere is one of tension and absurdity, typical of the whimsical and fantastical world of Wonderland.

image_4.image_path: ./fusion_research/fusion_dataset/novel/Alices Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass (Lewis Carroll) (1)/images/image_4.jpg
caption: CHAPTER I
down the rabbit-hole
image_4.context: So she was considering, in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, ‘and what is the use of a book,’ thought Alice, ‘without pictures or conversations?’ written, go without it, I am selling it at a price which is, to me, much the same thing as giving it away. image_4.description: The image is a black-and-white illustration of a rabbit dressed in human clothing, standing upright on its hind legs. The rabbit is wearing a checkered vest and a waistcoat, with a white shirt underneath. It has a long necktie and is holding a pocket watch in its right hand, which it appears to be checking. The rabbit also has a walking stick under its left arm. The background shows a grassy field with some tall grass and a dandelion. The rabbit looks hurried and concerned, as if it is running late for an important appointment. The overall atmosphere of the image conveys a sense of urgency and anxiety.

image_5.image_path: ./fusion_research/fusion_dataset/novel/Alices Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass (Lewis Carroll) (1)/images/image_5.jpg
image_5.context: Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage, not much larger than a rat-hole: she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw. How she longed to get out of that dark hall, and wander about among those beds of bright flowers and those cool fountains, but she could not even get her head through the doorway;\* ‘and even if my head would go through,’ thought poor Alice, ‘it would be of very little use without my shoulders. Oh, how I wish I could shut up like a telescope! made of solid glass: there was nothing on it but a tiny golden key,\* and Alice’s first idea was that this might belong to one of the doors of the hall; but, alas! either the locks were too large, or the key was too small, but at any rate it would not open any of them. However, on the second time round, she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before, and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high: she tried the little golden key in the lock, and to her great delight it fitted!
image_5.description: The image is a black-and-white illustration depicting a young girl, presumably Alice from the story 'Alice in Wonderland,' peering through a small door. The girl has long hair and is wearing a dress with a pinafore. She is bending forward slightly, her hand pulling back a curtain to reveal a tiny door. The scene suggests curiosity and anticipation as she looks through the doorway into what appears to be a garden or another world. The background is minimalistic, focusing attention on the girl and the small door. The overall atmosphere conveys a sense of wonder and adventure as Alice discovers a hidden passage.

image_6.image_path: ./fusion_research/fusion_dataset/novel/Alices Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass (Lewis Carroll) (1)/images/image_6.jpg
image_6.context: wise little Alice was not going to do that in a hurry. ‘No, I’ll look first,’ she said, ‘and see whether it’s marked “poison” or not’; for she had read several nice little stories about children who had got burnt, and eaten up by wild beasts, and other unpleasant things, all because they would not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them: such as, that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long; and that, if you cut your finger very deeply with a knife, it usually bleeds; and she had never forgotten that, few things indeed were really impossible. There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door, so she went back to the table, half hoping she might find another key on it, or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes: this time she found a little bottle on it (‘which certainly was not here before,’ said Alice), and tied round the neck of the bottle was a paper label, with the words ‘DRINK ME’ beautifully printed on it in large letters. It was all very well to say ‘Drink me,’ but the
image_6.description: The image is a black-and-white illustration of a young girl standing next to a small table. The girl has long, wavy hair and is wearing a short-sleeved dress with a full skirt. She is holding a small bottle in her right hand, which has a label that reads 'DRINK ME' in large letters. The girl appears to be examining the bottle closely, with a curious and cautious expression on her face. Her left hand is resting on her waist, and she is wearing knee-high socks and shoes. The table next to her is round and has a simple design with a single leg. The background is minimalistic, with no additional details or objects visible. The overall atmosphere of the image conveys a sense of wonder and caution as the girl contemplates the mysterious contents of the bottle.

image_7.image_path: ./fusion_research/fusion_dataset/novel/Alices Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass (Lewis Carroll) (1)/images/image_7.jpg
image_7.context: And so it was indeed: she was now only ten inches high, and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden. First, however, she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further: she felt a little nervous about this; ‘for it might end, you know,’ said Alice to herself, ‘in my going out altogether, like a candle. I wonder what I should be ‘What a curious feeling!’ said Alice. ‘I must be shutting up like a telescope!’ such as, that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long; and that, if you cut your finger very deeply with a knife, it usually bleeds; and she had never forgotten that, if you drink much from a bottle marked ‘poison,’ it is almost certain to disagree with you, sooner or later.  However, this bottle was not marked ‘poison,’ so Alice ventured to taste it, and, finding it very nice (it had, in fact, a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffy, and hot buttered toast), she very soon finished it off.
image_7.description: The image consists of a series of black asterisks (*) arranged in a pattern on a white background. image_8.image_path: ./fusion_research/fusion_dataset/novel/Alices Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking-Glass (Lewis Carroll) (1)/images/image_8.jpg
image_8.context: the pool of tears ‘Curiouser and curiouser!’ cried Alice (she was so much surprised, that for the moment she quite forgot how to speak good English). ‘Now I’m opening out like the largest telescope that ever was! Good-bye, feet!’ (for when she looked down at her feet, they seemed to be almost out of sight, they were getting so far off). ‘Oh, my poor little feet, I wonder who will put on your shoes and stockings for you now, dears? I’m sure $I$ sha’n’t be able! I shall be a great deal too far off to trouble myself CHAPTER II  She ate a little bit, and said anxiously to herself ‘Which way? Which way?’, holding her hand on the top of her head to feel which way it was growing; and she was quite surprised to find that she remained the same size. To be sure, this is what generally happens when one eats cake; but Alice had got so much into the way of expecting nothing but out-of-theway things to happen, that it seemed quite dull and stupid for life to go on in the common way. So she set to work, and very soon finished off the cake.

image_9.description: The image is a black-and-white illustration of Alice from the classic story 'Alice in Wonderland.' Alice is depicted standing and looking surprised or bewildered. She has long, wavy hair that falls past her shoulders and is wearing a dress with a high collar and puffed sleeves. Her posture is slightly bent forward, and one hand is placed on her chest while the other is resting on what appears to be a wall or a large object next to her. The expression on her face conveys a sense of curiosity and confusion, fitting the context where she is experiencing unusual growth. The background is minimalistic, with only a few lines suggesting a wall or a barrier next to her. The overall atmosphere of the image aligns with the whimsical and surreal tone of the story, capturing Alice's reaction to her extraordinary situation.
